newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada's Q3 earnings seen marred by metals.
newsitem.headline: Canada's Q3 earnings seen marred by metals.

text.p: (Dollars U.S. unless noted)
By Lydia Zajc
Lower profits from troubled base metals producers are clouding the otherwise improving corporate earnings picture for Canadian companies in the third quarter, analysts said Tuesday.
Richardson Greenshields of Canada analyst Dunnery Best forecast "very substantial declines in earnings" for major base metal firms.
"I think almost everywhere else you're going to see improvements year-over-year," Best said.
Canada's third-quarter earnings season is to kick off when Alcan Aluminium Ltd. reports on Thursday.
Best said he expects Alcan third-quarter earnings to fall to $0.35 a share from year earlier $0.61 a share, which came before an extraordinary loss of $1.24 a share for an asset writedown.
"There's some concerns that the metal group may not exactly report the (expected) numbers," Griffiths McBurney analyst Greg Misztela agreed.

Companies such as Inco Ltd., Noranda Inc. and Falconbridge Ltd. are likely to see earnings declines, Best said. One exception is likely to be Teck Corp. "Teck has a lot of coal in its production lineup and coal's been strong, so that will be the one offset," Best said.
But investors have anticipated disappointments, causing metal stock prices to slide after second-quarter earnings were hit by a drop in copper, nickel and other prices.
Markets were rocked in mid-June by the news that Sumitomo Corp. fired its head copper trader after he allegedly ran up a $1.8 billion loss.
Analysts forecast that Canada's major banks will lead the pack in earnings gains. The banks were expected to report their results for the quarter ended Oct. 31 in early December.
"They'll have a very good year-over-year comparison. I think quarter-over-quarter won't be quite as good," said Royal Bank of Canada vice-president of equities John Kellett.
The six largest banks, including Royal Bank of Canada and Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, have posted a string of record profits in recent years.
Best said Richardson Greenshields has increased earnings estimates for Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce six times so far this year.
Consumer products earnings will also rise, analysts said.
Another strong area will be Canada's important gold sector, which was buoyed by firmer bullion prices.
Earnings at energy firms will be fuelled by higher crude oil prices, analysts said.

Retail firms will benefit from recent cuts in short-term interest rates by Canada's central bank, spurring consumers to borrow and shop. "Bit by bit the underpinnings are being put in place for a more confident consumer that would eventually lead to better times," Kellett said.
Some high-technology firms have said they will report losses in the upcoming quarter, including Gandalf Technologies Inc. and Corel Corp., due to problems getting their products to market.
But technology heavyweights such as Northern Telecom Ltd. and Newbridge Networks Corp. will see higher earnings, Best said.
